update.description:
As discussed [in this thread](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/276/logging-part-8-ignition-tools-ign-log/activity#comment-62231607), the API of the `Playback` class may be misleading.

This PR refactors the functionality of `Playback` into `Playback` and `PlaybackHandle`. This is advantageous because:

1. It makes the control flow of playing back logs much more explicit
2. It reduces the number of potential errors or misuse that we need to handle

However, there are currently two disadvantages:

1. The log file is getting opened twice: once while setting up the playback, and a second time while starting the playback. This can probably be fixed with some adjustments to `raii_sqlite3`, so input from @sloretz would be very valuable for this. (Basically: can we get a lazy copy of the sqlite3 database, preferably without reopening the log file?)
2. The user becomes responsible for holding onto the `PlaybackHandlePtr` that gets returned by `Playback::Start()`. This is similar to the user's responsibility over `Node::Publisher`s, so I don't see this as a significant disadvantage.
update.title: Refactor Playback into Playback and PlaybackHandle

content.raw:
Yes and no. Intuitively, it would make sense, but there are two issues:

1. `DefaultToAllTopics()` is not const-qualified whereas this `Start()` function is const-qualified (because spawning a new playback handle shouldn't affect the state of the spawner).

2. The first bullet point is a natural consequence of the fact that calling here `DefaultToAllTopics()` will change the behavior of the `Playback` class. Consider this scenario:

    a. A user creates a `Playback` object `playback`.

    b. They call `playback->Start()` to spawn a handle that will playback all the topics.

    c. They call `playback->AddTopic("/some/topic")`.

    d. They call `playback->Start()` again.

If we call `this->DefaultToAllTopics()` here, then the second playback handle would play all of the topics again, even though the behavior that's defined by the documentation says that it should only play `/some/topic`.

    a. A user creates a Playback object playback.

    b. They call playback->Start() to spawn a handle that will playback all the topics.

    c. They call playback->AddTopic("/some/topic").

    d. They call playback->Start() again.

If we call this->DefaultToAllTopics() here, then the second playback handle would play all of the topics again, even though the behavior that's defined by the documentation says that it should only play /some/topic.

Done here: 72ff62f

There's a small caveat where we can't guarantee thread safety if the user (or a different library that's running in the same application as our library) makes some configuration changes to sqlite3 during runtime, but I think the danger of that is relatively low. We're expecting all the default recommended settings of sqlite3, so if a user changes those settings, then they're taking their fate into their own hands.

content.raw:
One method we could consider for fixing disadvantage (1) is to have the `Playback` class and all the `PlaybackHandler` instances that it spawns share a `std::shared_ptr<Log>`.

Since that `Log` instance would only be held internally by classes that we control, we can ensure that the log is only being read from. Then the question becomes: Is it okay for multiple different consumers of a `Log` to be simultaneously retrieving batches using `Log::QueryMessages(~)` and then simultaneously iterating through them? I think that's a feature that we should be able to support anyhow if we can't already; otherwise our `Batch::iterator` implementation may need some work. It's probably worth writing tests for that.

Then the question becomes: Is it okay for multiple different consumers of a Log to be simultaneously retrieving batches using Log::QueryMessages(~) and then simultaneously iterating through them? I think that's a feature that we should be able to support anyhow if we can't already; otherwise our Batch::iterator implementation may need some work. It's probably worth writing tests for that.
